On Fri, Apr 16, 2010 at 2:07 PM, mike amundsen <mamund@...> wrote:
> =
<snip>
>> o) Use rel=3D when clients will be selecting a link based on
>> r=
elationship semantics.
>> o) Use class=3D when clients will be selecting a =
link based on the
>> nature of the content itself.
> </snip>
>
> It sounds =
like you're using the CLASS attribute as a way of "tagging"
> content for o=
thers to use. It's an interesting approach. I assume you
> are decorating D=
IV, P, SPAN with these CLASS attributes. Will this
> kind of annotation con=
fuse typical CSS rendering details?

I'm actually adding the class attribut=
e directly on the link itself
(e.g. <a href=3D"..." class=3D"jobs">Job List=
ing</a>).  It doesn't affect
CSS rendering at all.  I can either take advan=
tage of that class name
in CSS, or add multiple classes (e.g. <a href=3D"..=
." class=3D"jobs
important">Job Listing</a>).

fo on the XHTML Meta Data Profiles (XMDP)
